courseTitle: Newton’s Law of Cooling and Thermodynamics

pageData.titleName2: Newton’s Law of Cooling and Thermodynamics

pageData.text: In this investigation, students collect data while a sample of heated water cools in 2 different environments, then graph the data and compare how the atmospheric temperature surrounding an object affects the rate at which the object cools.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Printed graph paper or computer with graphing software
Book or a piece of cardboard
Access to a stove or microwave
Pot or microwave-safe container that can hold 700 milliliters

pageData.text: Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of molecules which is determined by how fast those molecules are moving. Increased molecular movement can increase the speed of many reactions and processes but can also create increased resistance in electrical and magnetic systems. Because of this, some processes can only be performed at extremely low temperatures close to absolute 0 K (-273.15° C). For instance, the Large Hadron Collider at CERN, one of the most advanced particle accelerators in the world, only works at 1.9 K (-271.3° C). This is because the large magnets needed to keep the particle beam on course are made of superconductors which produce almost no resistance to electricity at very low temperatures, but if the temperature gets too high, can easily overheat and stop functioning. The process of super cooling the collider’s magnets down to the correct temperature requires transferring heat from Helium to liquid nitrogen to cool the helium down into a superfluid state. All in all, the process can take weeks and requires over 10,000 tons of liquid nitrogen to absorb the heat and reach the necessary temperature<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>.

1CERN. (2022). Cryogenics: Low temperatures, high performance. CERN.
https://home.cern/science/engineering/cryogenics-low-temperatures-high-performanceThe Large Hadron Collider/ATLAS at CERN by CERN is available under CC BY 2.0 at
https://www.flickr.com/photos/11304375@N07/2046228644

pageData.desc: One of the particle accelerator apparatuses of the Large Hadron Collider.
pageData.altText: One of the particle accelerator apparatuses of the Large Hadron Collider.

pageData.text: Thermodynamics explains how heat or thermal energy is converted to work or energy. Many systems can be described in terms of thermodynamics. Two physical laws that describe thermodynamic systems are the First and Second Laws of Thermodynamics.

The <button class='glossary-text'>First Law of Thermodynamics</button>, also known as the Law of Conservation of Energy, states that energy cannot be created or destroyed but may be converted from one form to another. For example, fuel in a car engine is burned to create heat. The heat is converted by the engine into mechanical energy that is used to produce work that turns the wheels and moves the car forward.

The <button class='glossary-text'>Second Law of Thermodynamics</button> states that heat only flows from a hot object to a cold object. When cold water is added to a volume of hot water, the cold water heats up and the hot water cools down. It may appear that the hot water absorbs the “coldness” from the cold water, but in reality, the heat energy from the hot water is transferred to the cold water. The exchange of heat continues until both volumes of water are at the same temperature. This is designated as thermal equilibrium (Figure 1).

pageData.desc: Figure 1: (a) Substances H and L are initially at different temperatures, and their atoms have different average kinetic energies. (b) When they contact each other, collisions between the molecules result in the transfer of kinetic (thermal) energy from the hotter to the cooler matter. (c) The two objects reach “thermal equilibrium” when both substances are at the same temperature and their molecules have the same average kinetic energy.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: (a) Substances H and L are initially at different temperatures, and their atoms have different average kinetic energies. (b) When they contact each other, collisions between the molecules result in the transfer of kinetic (thermal) energy from the hotter to the cooler matter. (c) The two objects reach “thermal equilibrium” when both substances are at the same temperature and their molecules have the same average kinetic energy.

pageData.text:
CNX Chem 05 01 HeatTrans1.jpg by OpenStax is available under CC BY 4.0 at
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:CNX_Chem_05_01_HeatTrans1.jpg
Heat can be transferred by <button class='glossary-text'>conduction</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>convection</button>, or <button class='glossary-text'>radiation</button> (Figure 2).

pageData.desc: Figure 2: A diagram of how a lit fireplace exemplifies radiation, conduction, and convection. The fireplace radiates heat into the room. The fireplace also conducts heat through its bottom surface into the floor of the room. Cold air in the room is drawn toward the fireplace and warmed, which warm air exits via the chimney by convection.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A diagram of how a lit fireplace exemplifies radiation, conduction, and convection. The fireplace radiates heat into the room. The fireplace also conducts heat through its bottom surface into the floor of the room. Cold air in the room is drawn toward the fireplace and warmed, which warm air exits via the chimney by convection.

pageData.text:
Figure 14.12 by OpenStax is available under CC BY 4.0 at
https://openstax.org/books/college-physics/pages/14-4-heat-transfer-methods

• Conduction occurs when heat is transferred between 2 objects that are physically touching, such as when you touch a hot iron.
  • Convection occurs in a fluid, such as air or water, and is the tendency for hotter material to rise and cooler material to sink.
  • Radiation occurs when you stand in the sunlight, because it is the transfer of energy through particles or waves (for example, light photons).

The rate of heat transfer can be determined using <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s Law of Cooling</button>. Newton’s Law of Cooling applies to an object that is at a different temperature than the surrounding atmosphere. Consider a cup of hot coffee in a room that is at room temperature or a glass of cold lemonade placed outside on a sunny day. According to the <button class='glossary-text'>Second Law of Thermodynamics</button>, the hot coffee will transfer heat to the cooler air and the cold lemonade will absorb heat from the warmer air. Newton’s Law of Cooling states that the rate at which energy is transferred depends on the temperature difference between the object that is cooling (or warming) and the surrounding atmosphere.
Rate of Cooling ∝ ΔT
Newton’s Law of Cooling applies to heat transfer by <button class='glossary-text'>convection</button>. It does not apply to heat loss by <button class='glossary-text'>radiation</button>.

pageData.question: Which is an example of conduction?

options.text: a hand touching a hot pan
condensation forming outside a cold glass of water
warm water rising
warmth coming off a hot tea kettle
a lizard warming itself in sunlight

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Conduction occurs when heat is transferred between 2 objects that are physically touching, such as when you touch a hot pan.

pageData.question: Which is an example of conduction?

options.text: wrapping hair around a hot curling iron
ice floating in water
the air on the second floor is warmer than the air on the ground floor of a building
a microwave oven heating leftover food
warmth coming off a hot stove top

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Conduction occurs when heat is transferred between 2 objects that are physically touching, such as when hair is curled with a curling iron.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Heat can be transferred by conduction (heat transfer between touching objects), convection (hotter material rises in a fluid), or radiation (transfer of energy as electromagnetic radiation). The rate of heat transfer can be determined using Newton’s Law of Cooling. Newton’s Law of Cooling applies to an object that is at a different temperature than the surrounding atmosphere. Consider a cup of hot coffee in a room that is at room temperature, or a glass of cold lemonade placed outside on a sunny day. According to the Second Law of Thermodynamics, hot coffee will transfer heat to the cooler air and the cold lemonade will absorb heat from the warmer air. Newton’s Law of Cooling states that the rate at which energy is transferred depends on the temperature difference between the object that is cooling (or warming) and the surrounding atmosphere.

The fireplace also conducts heat through its bottom surface into the floor of the room. Cold air in the room is drawn toward the fireplace and warmed, which warm air exits via the chimney by convection.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Heat can be transferred by conduction (heat transfer between touching objects), convection (hotter material rises in a fluid), or radiation (transfer of energy as electromagnetic radiation). The rate of heat transfer can be determined using Newton’s Law of Cooling. Newton’s Law of Cooling applies to an object that is at a different temperature than the surrounding atmosphere. Consider a cup of hot coffee in a room that is at room temperature, or a glass of cold lemonade placed outside on a sunny day. According to the Second Law of Thermodynamics, hot coffee will transfer heat to the cooler air and the cold lemonade will absorb heat from the warmer air. Newton’s Law of Cooling states that the rate at which energy is transferred depends on the temperature difference between the object that is cooling (or warming) and the surrounding atmosphere.

img.alt: Figure 2: A diagram of how a lit fireplace exemplifies radiation, conduction, and convection. The fireplace radiates heat into the room. The fireplace also conducts heat through its bottom surface into the floor of the room. Cold air in the room is drawn toward the fireplace and warmed, which warm air exits via the chimney by convection.

pageData.subTitle: An Everyday Example
pageData.text: When you put a hot drink in a thermos or a cold drink in an insulated cup, you are benefiting from <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s Law of Cooling</button>. Travel mugs and some insulated lunchboxes use technology based on this concept to reduce heat transfer (Figure 3).

pageData.desc: Figure 3: A vertical cross section of a thermos. The outermost layer of the thermos is a container. Inside the container is an inner vessel attached to the container by a rubber support at its base and spring centering devices on each side. The walls of the inner vessel are made up of two glass walls with silvered surfaces. The walls are separated by a vacuum. The inner vessel holds hot or cold liquid.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A vertical cross section of a thermos. The outermost layer of the thermos is a container. Inside the container is an inner vessel attached to the container by a rubber support at its base and spring centering devices on each side. The walls of the inner vessel are made up of two glass walls with silvered surfaces. The walls are separated by a vacuum. The inner vessel holds hot or cold liquid.

pageData.text:
Figure 14.30 by OpenStax is available under CC BY 4.0 at
https://openstax.org/books/college-physics/pages/14-conceptual-questions?query=thermos&target=%7B%22type%22%3A%22search%22%2C%22index%22%3A0%7D#eip-idm333128752

Many thermoses are made with a vacuum insulation that keeps hot liquids hotter and cold liquids cooler for longer. Vacuum flasks reduce heat transfer from all 4 types of possibilities when it comes to fluids: <button class='glossary-text'>conduction</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>convection</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>radiation</button>, and even evaporation. Most likely, the thermos that you use has a vacuum flask, or a double-silvered wall with a vacuum seal between the walls, and an air gap with plastic supports between the inner container (the part where you pour the liquid) and outer container (the part you hold).

• A thermos’s sealable lid reduces energy transfer that would otherwise be possible by conduction, convection, and radiation. These lids are generally made of plastic—a good insulator that reduces heat transfer from conduction. Convection currents cannot form, since they are blocked by the plastic lid, and as long as the lid is sealed, the molecules inside the thermos cannot escape through evaporation.
  • The silvered glass walls reduce energy transfer that could otherwise be possible through conduction and radiation. (Glass is a poor conductor, so it reduces energy transfer through conduction.)
  • The silver plating on the inside of the flask reflects the radiant heat of hot liquids back into the liquid and vice versa for cold liquids.
  • A vacuum seal between the glass walls of the flask reduces energy transfer through conduction and convection. Both types of energy transfer are prevented because a vacuum is, in essence, a lack of particles. Without particles between the walls, there is no medium to carry the energy.
  • Finally, the inner chamber that holds liquids is typically separated from the part that you can hold by plastic supports. These supports reduce energy transfer that could happen through conduction, because in addition to being a good insulator, plastic is a poor conductor.

In the following activities, you will test Newton’s Law of Cooling by allowing a hot liquid to cool in 2 different atmospheric temperatures, recording the temperature of the liquid under the 2 conditions during 1 hour, and then comparing the results.

pageData.question: Thermos lids are generally made of plastic, which is a good insulator that reduces heat transfer from which of the following?

options.text: conduction
convection
radiation
evaporation
thermal equilibrium

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Thermos lids are generally made of plastic, which is a good insulator that reduces heat transfer from conduction.

pageData.question: What is formed in a thermos between the walls that reduces energy transfer through conduction and convection?

options.text: vacuum
reflection
evaporation
thermal equilibrium
conduction

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A vacuum lacks particles. Without particles between the walls, there is no medium to carry energy via conduction or convection.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for activities 1 and 2 of this investigation. To prepare, you will label a container and boil water. In activity 1, you select a location. Then, you will transfer the water to the cup. Next, you will measure the air and water temperature. Then, you will record the temperature of the water every 10 minutes for 1 hour. Next, you will graph your data. In activity 2, you select a new location. Then, you will transfer the water to the cup. Next, you will measure the air and water temperature. Then, you will record the temperature of the water every 10 minutes for 1 hour. Finally, you will graph your data. You will then proceed to activity 3.

After completing activity 2, in activity 3, you select a new location. Then, you will transfer the water to the cup. Next, you will measure the air and water temperature. Then, you will record the temperature of the water every 10 minutes for 1 hour. While you wait, you will predict the temperature at given times using the equations in the lab manual. After 1 hour has elapsed, you will compare your calculated predictions to the actual result.

pageData.text: Wear safety goggles at all times while conducting this investigation. Personal protective equipment (PPE) may need to include gloves and an apron due to the nature of heating water on a stove.
Read all instructions for these activities before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate PPE.

Use caution when handling hot water. Wear safety goggles while boiling water to avoid eye injury. Turn off the stove or appliances when finished. Avoid direct contact with hot water and containers filled with hot water.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: In a coal power plant, coal is burned to generate heat, which heats water, making steam that causes a turbine to turn and generate electricity without any energy being destroyed. This is an example of which of the following?

options.text: the first law of thermodynamics
the second law of thermodynamics
Newton’s law of cooling
the third law of thermodynamics
heat transfer through a vacuum

assestmentData.question: You hold an ice cube in your hand and watch it melt while your hand begins to feel cold. According to the second law of thermodynamics, which of the following is occurring?

options.text: Heat is transferring from your hand to the ice cube.
Heat is transferring from the ice cube to your hand.
Cold is transferring from your hand to the ice cube.
Cold is transferring from the ice cube to your hand.
Heat is being transferred from your hand and cold is being transferred from the ice cube.

assestmentData.question: You fill up a tub with water. After testing the water, you determine it is too cold and add some additional hot water, bringing the water in the container to the correct temperature. This is an example of which of the following?

options.text: convection
conduction
radiation
specific Heat
enthalpy

assestmentData.question: Which of the following statements about Newton’s Law of Cooling is NOT true?

options.text: It applies to heat loss through radiation.
It applies to heat loss through convection.
It states that the rate of cooling relates to the temperature difference between the object and the atmosphere.
If the temperature difference is greater between the object and the atmosphere, the object will cool faster.
It obeys the second law of thermodynamics.

assestmentData.question: Many storage containers for maintaining temperature, like thermoses, have metallic, reflective inner surfaces. Which of the following best describes the purpose of this type of material?

options.text: to reflect the radiant heat of the substance back into it
to prevent heat transfer through convection by reducing air currents
to prevent any of the substance from leaking and thus transferring heat
to create a vacuum between the inner and outer layers, reducing conduction
to create a temperature differential within the substance to encourage convection and maintain heat

assestmentData.question: Which of the following safety considerations pertains to this investigation?

options.text: Wear safety goggles when boiling water to avoid eye injury.
Perform the investigation in a well-ventilated area.
The chemicals in this investigation are corrosive.
Keep the work area clear when using an open flame.
Label all equipment to prevent cross contamination.

assestmentData.question: This investigation uses a glass thermometer. Which of the following best describes the safe disposal of broken glass?

options.text: Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in a special receptacle on your school’s campus.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in a recycling bin.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following items will you need to supply yourself to complete this investigation?

options.text: a book or piece of cardboard
a large coin or metal washer
laundry bleach
food coloring
ice cubes

Read through the activities.
Obtain all materials.
Put on safety goggles.
Secure a location on a table or countertop where a foam cup (or beaker) of hot water can rest safely for 1 hour and be observed. Place a book or piece of cardboard on that location.
Label the container “Hot—Do Not Disturb” if it is possible that others may touch or disturb it during the activity.
Bring approximately 700 mL of tap water to a low boil in a pot on a stove or in a microwave using a microwave-safe container.

Note: For best results, place the cup (or beaker) on a book or a piece of cardboard to insulate it from the table or countertop surface. Make sure the room temperature is constant—do not turn the thermostat up or down, open any windows, or turn on a fan while performing the activities.
In Activity 1, you will observe the cooling of boiling water in a chosen location by making temperature observations every 10 minutes for one hour.

pages.title:
A
 Cooling of Hot Water in Location 1 (8 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Cooling of Hot Water in Location 1 (8 steps)

pageData.text: Carefully transfer 200 mL of hot water from the pot to the cup or beaker.

Place the container atop the book or piece of cardboard at a location where it can remain undisturbed for 1 hour. Remember, the location should be in an area where the temperature remains constant. Nonideal locations include a room with an outside door that is used often, where a fan is in operation, or in front of a window.
Immediately before beginning the activity, use the thermometer to measure the air temperature in the location. Record this value in Data Table 1 in the “Activity 1” column in row “Ta.”
Place the thermometer in the container to measure the water temperature. Allow the thermometer to reach a stable temperature (the temperature no longer increases).

Observe the thermometer carefully. When the water temperature begins to decrease, select a temperature a couple of degrees lower. Start the timer as soon as the temperature reaches that value. This is “time zero.”
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Observe the temperature of the water at time zero. Record this value in Data Table 1 for Activity 1 in the time row “0.”
Continue to observe the thermometer and record the water temperature every 10 minutes for an hour. Record these data in the correct time points in Data Table 1.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Use a sheet of graph paper or a software program to graph the temperature versus time data for the water as it cools.

In Activity 2, you will repeat Activity 1 in a different location and under different conditions.  You will observe the cooling of boiling water in this second location by making temperature observations every 10 minutes for one hour. You will then compare the rate of cooling between the locations.

pages.title:
A
 Cooling of Hot Water in Location 2 (8 steps)

A
 Cooling of Hot Water in Location 2 (8 steps)

typeBefore.text: Note: Since only one thermometer is provided, it is recommended that you conduct this activity after completing Activity 1.

pageData.text: Carefully, transfer 200 mL of hot water from the pot to the cup or beaker.

Place the container in a location that has a different temperature than that of the location used in Activity 1. Inside a refrigerator is a good option. Alternatively, the container can be placed outdoors if the temperature is cool/cold and likely to remain constant.
Immediately before beginning the activity, use the thermometer to measure the air temperature in the new location. Record this value in Data Table 1 in the “Activity 2” column in row “Ta.”
Place the thermometer in the container to measure the water temperature. Allow the thermometer to reach a stable temperature (the temperature no longer increases).

Observe the thermometer carefully. When the water temperature begins to decrease, select a temperature a couple of degrees lower. Start the timer as soon as the temperature reaches that value. This is “time zero.”
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Observe the temperature of the water at time zero. Record this value in Data Table 1 for Activity 2 in the time row “0.”
Continue to observe the thermometer and record the water temperature every 10 minutes for an hour. Record these data in the correct time points in Data Table 1.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Use a sheet of graph paper or a software program to graph the temperature versus time data for the water as it cools.

In Activity 3, you will repeat Activity 1, then compare the theoretical predicted temperature of a cooling liquid at a given time using the differential equation for <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s Law of Cooling</button> to your actual observations.
Note: This is an advanced activity. Consult with your instructor about your need to complete Activity 3. This may be used for advanced calculus-based Physics classes.
Predicting the Temperature of a Cooling Liquid Using
Note: This is an advanced activity. Consult with your instructor about your need to complete Activity 3. This may be used for advanced calculus-based Physics class.
Newton’s Law of Cooling can be expressed as the following differential equation:

pageData.desc: begin fraction d T over d t end fraction equals negative k begin paren T minus T sub a end paren
pageData.altText: begin fraction d T over d t end fraction equals negative k begin paren T minus T sub a end paren

pageData.text: where T = temperature of the substance at time t, Ta = temperature of the atmosphere, and k = a constant.
The expression

pageData.desc: begin fraction d T over d t end fraction
pageData.altText: begin fraction d T over d t end fraction

pageData.text: represents the temperature change with respect to time. The equation for Newton’s Law of Cooling indicates that the temperature change with respect to time is proportional to the difference between the temperature of the substance and the temperature of the surroundings. This means that a glass of hot water cools more rapidly in a cold room than in a hot room.

The solution for the differential equation is an exponential function that gives the temperature of an object as it cools (or warms) as a function of time. If all the constants in the function and the initial conditions at a given time are known, the temperature at a future time can be calculated.
Begin solving the differential equation by rearranging the equation:

pageData.desc: begin fraction d T over begin paren T minus T sub a end paren end fraction equals negative k d t
pageData.altText: begin fraction d T over begin paren T minus T sub a end paren end fraction equals negative k d t

pageData.text: Integrating both sides gives:

pageData.desc: begin integral begin fraction d T over begin paren T minus T sub a end paren end fraction equals negative k end integral d t
pageData.altText: begin integral begin fraction d T over begin paren T minus T sub a end paren end fraction equals negative k end integral d t

pageData.desc: natural log begin absolute value begin paren T minus T sub a end paren end absolute value equals negative k t plus C sub 1
pageData.altText: natural log begin absolute value begin paren T minus T sub a end paren end absolute value equals negative k t plus C sub 1

pageData.text: This means:

pageData.desc: begin absolute value begin paren T minus T sub a end paren end absolute value equals e begin sup negative k t plus C sub 1 end sup
pageData.altText: begin absolute value begin paren T minus T sub a end paren end absolute value equals e begin sup negative k t plus C sub 1 end sup

pageData.text: This equation can be written as:

pageData.desc: begin absolute value begin paren T minus T sub a end paren end absolute value equals e begin sup negative k t end sup e begin sup C sub 1 end sup
pageData.altText: begin absolute value begin paren T minus T sub a end paren end absolute value equals e begin sup negative k t end sup e begin sup C sub 1 end sup

pageData.text: The quantity eC1 is a constant that can be expressed as C2.

pageData.desc: begin absolute value begin paren T minus T sub a end paren end absolute value equals C sub 2 e begin sup negative k t end sup
pageData.altText: begin absolute value begin paren T minus T sub a end paren end absolute value equals C sub 2 e begin sup negative k t end sup

pageData.text: There are 2 general solutions for this equation. One solution considers a substance at temperature T that is hotter than the ambient temperature Ta. The expression on the left side of the equal sign is expressed in terms of absolute value; therefore, (T – Ta) can be either positive or negative.
If (T – Ta ) > 0 T – Ta = C2e–kt T = C2e–kt + Ta
If (T – Ta ) < 0 T – Ta = C2e–kt T = C2e–kt – Ta
Transfer 200 mL of hot water from the pot to the cup or beaker.

Place the container atop the book or piece of cardboard at a location where it can remain undisturbed for 1 hour. Remember, the location should be in an area where the temperature remains constant. Nonideal locations include a room with an outside door that is used often, where a fan is in operation, or in front of a window.
Immediately before beginning the experiment, use the thermometer to measure the air temperature in the location. Record this value in Data Table 2 in the “Measured Temperature” column in row “Ta.”
Place the thermometer in the container to measure the water temperature. Allow the thermometer to reach a stable temperature (the temperature no longer increases).

Observe the thermometer carefully. When the water temperature begins to decrease, select a temperature a couple of degrees lower. Start the timer as soon as the temperature reaches that value. This is “time zero.”
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Observe the temperature of the water at time zero. Record this value in Data Table 2 in the time row “0.”
Continue to observe the thermometer and record the water temperature every 10 minutes for an hour. Record these data in the correct time points in Data Table 2.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: As the water cools, solve the following sample problem using data from your experiment to calculate the water temperature at 40 minutes.

Sample ProblemConsider a 200 mL sample of water with an initial temperature of 72 °C in a room with air temperature Ta = 25 °C. At 10 minutes, the water temperature is 59 °C. What will the water temperature be at 40 minutes?Since the object is cooling, begin with the exponential function:T(t) = C2e–kt + TaFind C2 by substituting the time and temperature data for T(0). At t = 0, the temperature is 72 °C. When t = 0, e–kt is 1.T(t) = 72 = C2 + 25∴C2 = 47Now use another data point to find the value for k:T(10) = 59 = 47e–k (10) = 2534 = 47e–k (10)0.72 = e–k (10)Calculate the natural log of both sides:ln(0.72) = -k (10)-0.324 = -k (10)k = 0.0324Now use these 2 constants (C2 and k) to calculate the predicted temperature T at 40 minutes.T(t) = C2e–kt + TaT(40) = 47e–(0.0324)(40) + 25T(40) = 38 °C

Repeat this sample problem using data you collected in Activity 3 for the water temperature at times t = 0 and t = 10. Compare the value you calculate for time t = 40 with the value you measured in the experiment.

1. Dispose of the water.
  2. Carefully dry the equipment, and return it to the central materials set.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

tableData.text: Calculated Temperature (°C) Using Newton’s Law of Cooling Equation

pageData.text: In order for your instructor to be able to open your video links, please select the "Save as PDF" option rather than "Print to PDF".

pageData.altText: Figure 1: (a) Substances H and L are initially at different temperatures, and their atoms have different average kinetic energies. (b) When they contact each other, collisions between the molecules result in the transfer of kinetic (thermal) energy from the hotter to the cooler matter. (c) The two objects reach “thermal equilibrium” when both substances are at the same temperature and their molecules have the same average kinetic energy.

Figure 2: A diagram of how a lit fireplace exemplifies radiation, conduction, and convection. The fireplace radiates heat into the room. The fireplace also conducts heat through its bottom surface into the floor of the room. Cold air in the room is drawn toward the fireplace and warmed, which warm air exits via the chimney by convection.

Figure 3: A vertical cross section of a thermos. The outermost layer of the thermos is a container. Inside the container is an inner vessel attached to the container by a rubber support at its base and spring centering devices on each side. The walls of the inner vessel are made up of two glass walls with silvered surfaces. The walls are separated by a vacuum. The inner vessel holds hot or cold liquid.

A map of the procedural workflow for activities 1 and 2 of this investigation. To prepare, you will label a container and boil water. In activity 1, you select a location. Then, you will transfer the water to the cup. Next, you will measure the air and water temperature. Then, you will record the temperature of the water every 10 minutes for 1 hour. Next, you will graph your data. In activity 2, you select a new location. Then, you will transfer the water to the cup. Next, you will measure the air and water temperature. Then, you will record the temperature of the water every 10 minutes for 1 hour. Finally, you will graph your data. You will then proceed to activity 3.

After completing activity 2, in activity 3, you select a new location. Then, you will transfer the water to the cup. Next, you will measure the air and water temperature. Then, you will record the temperature of the water every 10 minutes for 1 hour. While you wait, you will predict the temperature at given times using the equations in the lab manual. After 1 hour has elapsed, you will compare your calculated predictions to the actual result.

data.title: Conduction
data.content: occurs when heat is transferred between 2 objects that are physically touching

data.title: Convection
data.content: occurs in a fluid, such as air or water, and is the tendency for hotter material to rise and cooler material to sink

data.title: First Law of Thermodynamics
data.content: states that energy cannot be created or destroyed but may be converted from one form to another; also called the Law of Conservation of Energy

data.title: Newton’s Law of Cooling
data.content: the rate of heat loss of a body is directly proportional to the difference in the temperatures between the body and its environment

data.title: Radiation
data.content: the transfer of energy through particles or waves (for example, light photons)

data.title: Second Law of Thermodynamics
data.content: states that heat only flows from a hot object to a cold object
